metadata.title: Telomerization of 1,3-butadiene with highly substituted alcohols using Pd/NHC-catalysts — Structure-reactivity-relationship of the O-nucleophile

Scheme 1 Telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene with an alcohol. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The Pd(IMes)(dvds) precursor. Telomerization of 1,3-butadiene with highly substituted alcohols using Pd/NHC-catalysts — Structure-reactivity-relationship of the O-nucleophile Thiemo A. Faßbach a Robin Kirchmann a Arno Behr a Steffen Romanski b Dirk Leinweber b Andreas J. Vorholt a ⁎ a Technische Universität Dortmund, Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie, Emil-Figge-Str. 66, Dortmund, D‐44227 Germany Technische Universität Dortmund Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie Emil-Figge-Str. 66 Dortmund D‐44227 Germany b Clariant AG, Frankfurt am Main, D-65929 Germany Clariant AG Frankfurt am Main D-65929 Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Catalytic telomerization of 1,3-butadiene with alcohols is a catalytic reaction and an effective tool to synthesize 2,7-octadienyl ethers with different characteristics depending on the alcoholic substrate. While Pd/phosphine type catalysts were studied in depth, highly active Pd/NHC (=N-heterocyclic carbene) catalysts have been studied in the telomerization almost exclusively along with methanol. In the course of employing alcohols from renewables, e.g., lignin, cellulose or terpenes etc., a deeper understanding of the reactivity of these catalysts is needed. In this work, we present comprehensive investigations with linear and branched alcohols of different chain-lengths. Distinct tendencies in reaction behavior between primary and secondary alcohols were found and the lower reactivity of secondary alcohols could clearly be attributed to electronic properties, along with steric hindrance. Furthermore, the influence of double bonds in the alcohol chain has been studied. Interestingly, alcohols with double bonds that are not conjugated to the hydroxyl groups were shown to be more active than saturated alcohols. Allylic alcohols, however, are significantly less reactive than their saturated analogs. With the gathered information, we were able to deduce a structure reactivity-relationship of certain functional groups and substitution patterns. These findings were proved by employing terpenols to gain new allylic terpenol ethers. Keywords Telomerization Palladium N-Heterocyclic carbenes Homogeneous catalysis Renewables 1 Introduction The dimerization of 1,3‐dienes (e.g. 1,3-butadiene) along with an addition of a nucleophile is called a telomerization (Scheme 1 ) [1]. It is mostly catalyzed by homogeneous palladium/phosphine complexes, but other metals like nickel [2] or platinum [3] have been reported to be active as well. Since its discovery in 1966 [4], the telomerization reaction was applied to a variety of nucleophiles and dienes. Regarding the diene substrate, there are only a few examples apart from 1,3‐butadiene that have been employed successfully. The most important one is isoprene [5–8], but dienes with longer chains, like 1,3‐pentadiene and 1,3‐hexadiene could also be converted [9,10]. To this date the largest 1,3‐diene employed in a telomerization is β‐myrcene [11,12]. While the diene is limited to only a few compounds, there are many examples for different nucleophiles used in this reaction. The most simple oxygen nucleophile is water, which can be converted to octadienols, when 1,3‐butadiene is applied. This reaction was realized as an industrial process, which is run by Kuraray with an output of approximately 5,000t/a [13]. The most important nucleophiles are alcohols. From short, primary alcohols [14,15] over polyvalent alcohols, like glycols [16–18] or glycerol [19–21], to polyols like sugars [22–27], various catalytic systems with different ligands have been engaged. On an even higher scale (>100,000t/a) the telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene with methanol is run by Dow Chemicals in Tarragona, in order to finally produce 1-octene. Another type of widely used nucleophiles are amines [5,28], which often show higher reaction rates than alcohols [29]. Apart from that, there are few more nucleophiles, like CO2 [30–32], phenols [33–35] and acids [36], that have been employed. In the last years, Beller et al. introduced N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands as highly active alternatives to the common phosphine ligands [37,38]. It was shown that these ligands are very effective for telomerizations with alcohols and amines [39]. Especially the palladium precursor Pd(IMes) (dvds) (=[(1,3-dimesitylimidazolin-2-ylidene)-Pd‐ƞ 2,ƞ 2-1,1,3,3‐tetramethyl-1,3-divinyl-disiloxane]) (Scheme 2 ) is active at very low concentrations (down to 0.0003mol%) and shows high selectivities in the telomerization [40]. Furthermore, it is a commercially available compound, thus studies regarding an industrial use are eligible. It is known that the reactivity of the palladium/NHC catalysts strongly depends on the nature of the nucleophile, meaning the type (e.g. O-nucleophile or N-nucleophile) and the substitution pattern of the nucleophile [29]. While there are comprehensive studies on the influence of the alcohol using Pd/PR3-catalysts [15,41], there are no equivalent studies in which Pd/NHC-catalysts have been employed. However, the high activities with methanol and hints that these new catalysts are capable of converting sterically and electronically more demanding alcohols make in-depth studies in this field an attractive research goal. A comprehensive understanding of reactivities with various alcohols could broaden the spectra of the telomerization. Thus, enabling new catalytic conversions of renewable substrates, in this work the gained insights of the structure-reactivity-relationship were transferred to terpenols using the highly active Pd/IMes catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Chemicals were purchased from Acros Organics (Geel, Belgium), Sigma-Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany) and TCI (Tokyo, Japan). 1,3‐butadiene was obtained from Messer (Bad Soden, Germany). All chemicals were employed without drying or any further purification. Catalyst Pd(IMes)(dvds) was donated by Umicore (Brussels, Belgium). 2.2 Telomerization experiments All reactions were performed in a 25mL custom-made stainless steel autoclave [42]. The catalyst was weighed directly into the reactor pot. Then the alcohol (50mmol) was added gravimetrically, as well as NaOH (0.5mmol). The reactor was closed and 1,3‐butadiene (100mmol) was added volumetrically via a pressure-resistant tube. To determine the accurate mass of the added 1,3‐butadiene, the reactor was weighed before and after addition. Afterwards the reactor was pressurized with 8bar argon and placed in a heated aluminum block at 80°C. The reaction was magnetically stirred at 500rpm. After 4h the reaction was stopped using an ice-bath. 2.3 Product analysis Routine gas chromatographic analyses were performed on an Agilent 7890B instrument (Santa Clara, USA) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP-5 capillary column (30m, diameter 0.32mm, film thickness 0.25μm) connected to an auto sampler (7693) and an injector (G4513A). GC–MS analyses of the products were carried out on an Agilent 5977A MSD (70eV). NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DRX spectrometers with TMS as internal standard. CDCl3 was used as solvent and purchased from Deutero. 3 Results & discussion Inspired by the high activities of the catalytic system Pd/IMes and the capability of converting alcohols to their respective octadienyl ethers, where the classical Pd/PR3-catalysts fail, we wanted to evaluate the scope of the telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene with alcohols systematically. With a clear structure-reactivity-relationship at hand the feasibility of the telomerization with any alcohol was assessable. The first investigations considered linear, primary alcohols, since they are the most active O‐nucleophiles. 3.1 Saturated alcohols 3.1.1 Linear alcohols As shown in Table 1 , the catalytic system Pd/IMes is compatible with linear, primary alcohols over a wide range of chain lengths without significant changes to the activity or selectivity. The yield of the telomers is about 70%–75%, the dimer yields are about 15%–20%. The reaction conditions should demonstrate the reaction behavior well and were applied with a focus on high substrate concentrations and catalyst loadings, leading to high space-time-yields. Therefore we applied stoichiometric substrate ratios and low catalyst concentrations along with a base. The base is of great importance for Pd/NHC-catalysts to maintain high reaction rates. As Völkl et al. showed with kinetic studies, the produced alkoxide reacts with a transition state in the catalytic cycle [43]. Higher selectivities towards the telomerization product could be achieved by a significant excess of the nucleophile. Under these reaction conditions methanol is less active than the alcohols with longer chains. In this context Cavell et al. suggested a stabilization of the catalyst by longer carbon chains [9]. Another reason that should be discussed at this point is the nucleophilicity of the respective alkoxide. Methanol is the strongest acid among the tested alcohols, its nucleophilicity is therefore the lowest. Disregarding any steric considerations, this could be the reason for the slightly lower activity compared to the other linear, primary alcohols. Every primary, linear alcohol longer than methanol leads to equal results over a long range of chain lengths, which is a striking advantage compared to phosphine ligands. The catalysts with triphenylphosphine ligands suffer from a severe loss of selectivity with increasing chain lengths of the alcohols, yielding large quantities of dimers. The TON of the Pd/PPh3-catalyst decreases below 2,000 with alcohols longer than C5, where the selectivity towards the telomers is only about 60% [14]. A higher selectivity with higher alcohols were only achieved with more basic phosphines, e.g. triethylphosphine, like Patrini showed [41]. In the case of n‐octanol for example, they reported high conversions and selectivities towards the telomers, resulting in TONs up to 1,800. With the Pd/IMes catalyst a tenfold of these TONs are achievable (Table 1). Linear alcohols are obviously highly active compounds in the Pd/IMes catalyzed telomerization, but only if the hydroxyl group is located at the end of the carbon chain. The corresponding secondary alcohols are much less reactive. Not only is the formation of telomers reduced, but also the conversion of 1,3‐butadiene in general. In the case of the employed pentanols, the conversion decreases from 92% with 1‐pentanol over 38% (2-pentanol) to 25% (3‐pentanol). This drastic decline raises the question, which influence plays the most important role in the catalytic cycle. There are either electronic properties that inhibit the catalytic conversion or the decrease takes place only for sterical reasons. 3.1.2 Cyclic alcohols We have shown that secondary alcohols suffer from a much lower activity in the telomerization than their primary equivalent. For many renewable substrates offer secondary alcohols, it is important to determine, whether these hydroxyl groups can be converted with this catalytic system. In order to separate the steric from the electronic influence, we employed the corresponding cyclic alcohols (Table 2 ) and compared the results with the ones shown in Table 1. The results show that cyclic alcohols are more reactive than the secondary, linear ones with the same chain length. For example cyclo‐pentanol yields 48% of the telomerization product, which is twice as much as with 2‐ and 3‐pentanol. Again, it can be stated, that the Pd/IMes‐catalyst is much more versatile than Pd/PPh3, as there is no formation of telomers in the telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene with e.g. cyclohexanol at all using these catalysts [15]. Due to the nearly identical electronic properties of the hydroxyl function in cyclo‐ and 2‐ or 3‐pentanol, this increase can be attributed to the lower steric demand. This is also consistent with the decrease in activity with larger rings of the cyclo-alcohols. We already showed that the longer chain itself does not interfere with the reaction, but since the bond angle for larger cycles increase, the steric demand does as well. We could successfully increase the yield of telomers by decreasing the steric demand of the secondary alcohol, using cyclo‐pentanol. Still, the primary analog 1‐pentanol yields significantly more products. We therefore suggest that there are electronic reasons for the higher activity of primary than of secondary alcohols in the Pd/IMes catalyzed telomerization. There are many renewable, primary alcohols, like terpenols, bearing non‐linear alcohol moieties. The activity of primary alcohols benefits from electronic reasons rather than from sterical ones, we therefore wanted to find the sterical limits of this reaction. 3.1.3 Branched alcohols Since the electronic properties of the employed alcohols are obviously as important as the steric hindrance, we wanted to know how far this concept can be generalized. Therefore primary alcohols with bulkier alkyl chains were used (Table 3 ). Obviously, an iso‐branch has little to no influence, neither on the conversion nor the selectivity in the telomerization. In both cases, iso‐pentanol and iso‐butanol, the reactivity did not change significantly compared to the linear alcohol. Surprisingly, even the sterically very demanding neo-pentanol could be successfully converted into the corresponding ether with comparably good yields of 57%. This value exceeds the product yields reached with any secondary pentanol employed in this study. This substantiates the finding that the steric influence is not as important to the reactivity as the electronic properties of the alcohol moiety. 3.2 Unsaturated alcohols 3.2.1 Alkenols Many natural occurring alcohols have unsaturated backbones, e.g. terpenols. Regarding the importance of electronic properties of the alcohol in the Pd/IMes catalyzed telomerization, it is of great interest to examine the reaction behavior of unsaturated alcohols. It has to be said that a double bond within an alcohol structure changes both, the electronic and the steric attributes of the substrate. At first, we carried out reactions with alcohols containing a double bond, but not an allylic hydroxyl group (Table 4 ) and compared the results to the saturated analogs. 5‐Hexen‐1‐ol was found to be converted almost completely, while only 82% of the desired product was yielded. The reason for this is the palladium catalyzed isomerization of the unsaturated alcohol to the aldehyde, followed by an aldol condensation. The aldol condensation product was identified via GC–MS and its yield was about 10%. It is known that linear, unsaturated alcohols can undergo an isomerization with palladium catalysts and that unsaturated alcohols with substituted double bonds are more stable under these conditions. Therefore isoprenol (3-methylbut-3-en-1-ol) was employed, which led to higher product yields, as expected. These two results show that unsaturated alcohols in general are more active in the Pd/IMes catalyzed telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene than saturated ones. At first glance, higher electron density increases repulsion with the palladium-allyl-complex, and should therefore inhibit approximation of the nucleophile. 3.2.2 Allylic alcohols To clarify the influence of double bonds in the alcohol during the telomerization, we tested allylic alcohols and compared the results to the corresponding saturated alcohols (Table 5 ). The telomerization of allylic alcohols was only described by Beger and Reichel in 1973 with Pd/PPh3 catalysts, yielding small amounts of 10% of the telomerization product [15]. This is equivalent to a TON of only 200. Especially the telomer of 1,3‐butadiene with allyl alcohol could be an interesting building block for polymers, being an α,ω-unsaturated ether. The chosen catalytic system leads to significantly higher yields, than the before mentioned Pd/P catalysts. While the yield could be doubled, the TON multiplies by 24. The NHC ligand obviously enables the telomerization of unsaturated alcohols much more than the classical Pd/PR3 catalysts do. But the product yields are still significantly lower, compared to those with the saturated alcohols (Table 1). The allylic alcohols are less reactive, which could be explained by the higher electron density due to the double bond next to the hydroxyl group. This potentially hinders the approach of the alkoxylate to the catalyst. Remarkably, we found no aldol condensation products of the conjugated aldehyde of the allylic alcohols, unlike with 5‐hexen‐1‐ol. We put the gathered information of the employed model substrates in a “substrate map” (Scheme 3 ) giving a semi-quantitative overview how alcohols react in the Pd/IMes catalyzed telomerization (Scheme 4 ). 3.2.3 Terpenols With the gained insights to telomerization reactions with unsaturated alcohols at hand, we employed renewable alcohols with the molecule patterns from the model substrates, like terpenols in our reactions (Scheme 5 ). The non-allylic alcohol citronellol yields more than twice as much product, as the allylic alcohol nerol (Table 6 ). These results are in accordance with the results from allyl alcohol and crotyl alcohol and their respective saturated analogs. Allylic alcohols are generally less reactive in the telomerization reaction. The secondary, long chain alcohol methyl ricinoleate could not be converted to its respective octadienyl ether, neither were any 1,3‐butadiene dimers formed. These results show that the aligned structure-reactivity-relationship is valid for the employed renewable nucleophiles. 4 Conclusions In the presented work, we examined the possibilities of the palladium/NHC catalyzed telomerization of 1,3‐butadiene with higher substituted alcohols. Using the popular IMes ligand, we achieved constantly high yields of primary, linear alcohols of about 75% up to a chain length of eight. This is a noticeable improvement compared to the Pd/PR3 catalysts. When secondary alcohols are employed, the trend of decreasing yields matches the trend with phosphine ligands, still the overall yields and TONs are significantly higher with the IMes ligand. To distinguish between electronic influences of secondary hydroxyl groups and the steric hindrance, we employed cyclic alcohols. The sterical advantage over non-cyclic secondary alcohols resulted in higher yields (YTelo =48% for cyclo-pentanol), but not to the extent of primary alcohols (YTelo =75% for 1-pentanol). To determine the influence of steric hindrance, we then applied primary alcohols with very bulky alkyl moieties. Interestingly, even the sterically challenging neo‐pentanol was converted to its octadienyl ether with a yield of 57%, exceeding the product yield of any secondary alcohol employed in this work. A double bond within the alkyl chain of an alcohol does not interfere with the telomerization reaction, but yet increases reactivity compared to the saturated analogs. However, if the double bond forms an allylic alcohol, the reaction suffers from a severe loss of activity. This behavior could be demonstrated on short chain alcohols, like allyl alcohol vs. 1-propanol (24% vs. 72% yield of telomers). We were able to assign the reaction behavior to certain functional groups and substitution patterns. With the gained structure-reactivity-relationship, we were able to estimate the reactivity of renewable nucleophiles, like terpenols. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a telomerization with terpenols, allylic and non-allylic ones, yielding terpene‐derived (di‐)allylic ethers. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic telomerization of 1,3-butadiene with alcohols is a catalytic reaction and an effective tool to synthesize 2,7-octadienyl ethers with different characteristics depending on the alcoholic substrate. While Pd/phosphine type catalysts were studied in depth, highly active Pd/NHC (=N-heterocyclic carbene) catalysts have been studied in the telomerization almost exclusively along with methanol. In the course of employing alcohols from renewables, e.g., lignin, cellulose or terpenes etc., a deeper understanding of the reactivity of these catalysts is needed. In this work, we present comprehensive investigations with linear and branched alcohols of different chain-lengths. Distinct tendencies in reaction behavior between primary and secondary alcohols were found and the lower reactivity of secondary alcohols could clearly be attributed to electronic properties, along with steric hindrance. Furthermore, the influence of double bonds in the alcohol chain has been studied. Interestingly, alcohols with double bonds that are not conjugated to the hydroxyl groups were shown to be more active than saturated alcohols. Allylic alcohols, however, are significantly less reactive than their saturated analogs. With the gathered information, we were able to deduce a structure reactivity-relationship of certain functional groups and substitution patterns. These findings were proved by employing terpenols to gain new allylic terpenol ethers.
coredata.dc:title: Telomerization of 1,3-butadiene with highly substituted alcohols using Pd/NHC-catalysts — Structure-reactivity-relationship of the O-nucleophile
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
